name: Conium
Relationship: Compare: SCIRRHINUM - Cancer nosode - (cancerous diathesis; enlarged glands; cancer of breast; worms); BARYT.; HYDRAST.; IOD.; KALI-PHOS.; HYOS.; CURARE.
Modalities: Worse: turning or rising in bed; celibacy; before and during menses
Better: from letting limbs hand down

Stool: Heat and burning in rectum during stool
Eyes: In superficial inflammation, as in phlyctenular conjunctivitis and keratitis
The slightest ulceration or abrasion will cause the most intense photophobia
Stomach: Terrible nausea, acrid heartburn, and acid eructations; worse on going to bed
Soreness about the root of tongue
Amelioration from eating and aggravation a few hours after meals; acidity and burning; painful spot the level of the sternum
Abdomen: Severe aching in and around the liver
Chronic jaundice, and pains in right hypochondrium
Respiratory: Want of breath on taking the least exercise; oppressed breathing, constriction of chest; pains in chest
Dry cough, almost continuous, hacking; worse, evening and at night; caused by dry spot in larynx with itching in chest and throat, when lying down, talking or laughing, and during pregnancy
Head: Headache, stupefying, with nausea and vomiting of mucus, with a feeling as of foreign body under the skull
Dull occipital pain on rising in morning
Vertigo, when lying down, and when turning over in bed, when turning head sidewise, or turning eyes; worse, shaking head, slight noise or conversation of others, especially towards the left
Tightness as if both temples were compressed; worse after a meal
Scorched feeling of top
Bruised, semi lateral pains
Ears: Defective hearing; discharge from ear blood colored
Mind: Memory weak; unable to sustain any mental effort
No inclination for business or study; takes no interest in anything
Depressed, timid, averse to society, and afraid of being alone
Back: Dull aching in lumbar and sacral region
Ill effects of bruises and shocks to spine
Female: Wants to press breast hard with hand
Mammae lax and shrunken, hard, painful to touch
Ill effects of repressed sexual desire or suppressed menses, or from excessive indulgence
Ovaritis; ovary enlarged, indurated; lancinating pain
Breasts enlarge and become painful before and during menses
Menses delayed and scanty; parts sensitive
Skin: Night and morning sweat, with offensive odor, and smarting in skin
Glands enlarged and indurated, also mesenteric
Tumors; piercing pains; worse, at night
Yellow skin, with papular eruption; yellow finger-nails
Axillary glands pain, with numb feeling down arm
Sweat as soon as one sleeps, or even when closing eyes
Extremities: Heavy, weary, paralyzed; trembling; hands unsteady; fingers and toes numb
Muscular weakness, especially of lower extremities
Putting feet on chair relieves pain

details: An old remedy, rendered classical by Plato's graphic description of its employment in the death of Socrates. The ASCENDING PARALYSIS it produces, ending in death by failure of respiration, show the ultimate tendency of many symptoms produced in the provings, for which Conium is an excellent remedy, such as difficult gait, trembling, sudden loss of strength while walking, painful stiffness of legs, etc. Such a condition is often found in old age, a time of weakness, languor, local congestions, and sluggishness. This is the special environment that Conium chooses to manifest its action. It corresponds to the debility, hypochondriasis, urinary troubles, weakened memory, sexual debility found here. Troubles at the change of life, old maids and bachelors. Growth of tumors invite it also. General feeling as if bruised by blows. Great debility in the morning in bed. WEAKNESS OF BODY AND MIND TREMBLING, and palpitation. Cancerous diathesis. Arteriosclerosis. Caries of sternum. Enlarged glands. Acts on the glandular system, engorging and indurating it, altering its structure like scrofulous and cancerous conditions. Tonic after grippe. Insomnia of multiple neuritis.
dosage: Best in higher potencies given infrequently, especially for growth, paretic states, etc. Otherwise sixth to thirtieth.
